With her approachable demeanor and empathetic heart, she stands as a bridge between the police force and the residents they serve.

In the face of adversity, Sgt. White exhibits nerves of steel — a composure that has been honed over countless life-or-death situations. Her focus is unwavering, her courage unshakable. This resolve has earned her numerous accolades, including the prestigious BPD’s Lifesaver Award for her heroic intervention that saved a man threatening to jump from a bridge.

Sgt. White’s impact extends far beyond the line of duty. As a devoted family woman, she sets an example of balance and dedication that resonates with her son, who works with another local law enforcement agency. She also has a daughter-in-law and three grandchildren. Sgt. White’s involvement in the community, particularly in mentoring women and participating in outreach ministry, shows her commitment to uplifting others.

Her advice to women contemplating a career in law enforcement is a soul-stirring message: seek knowledge, embrace training and never settle for less than your full potential. Sgt. White encourages women to remain true to themselves, to serve with compassion and humility, and to stand firm in the knowledge that they, too, can make a difference.

She is definitely forging a path for future generations of women warriors in blue.

March 28 – Gwendolyn Cook-Bibb

Illegal dumping had become such a problem in Gwendolyn Cook-Bibb’s East Brownville neighborhood that as soon as City of Birmingham crews picked up abandoned couches, old refrigerators and stoves on a stretch of road, someone illegally dumped more.

Fed up with the violators dumping on a major thoroughfare, Cook-Bibb started an anti-dumping campaign in 2023. She organized neighborhood cleanups and ordered metal signs to discourage the illegal dumping of major appliances. It worked.

“The anti-dumping campaign is good, and I would recommend it to other neighborhoods and other communities,” said Cook-Bibb, who is president of the East Brownville neighborhood. “It’s not hard to start. I created our first signs, and ordered them from a place on the internet. And then, somebody told me about Temu, and I ordered some from them.”

“I have some signs in my trunk right now. I keep them, so if I ride the neighborhood and I see a spot that needs a little attention, I’ll put it out. But if I can’t, I’ll get somebody to put it up.”

What Cook-Bibb thinks changed the behavior was changing the approach. “We had signs that said, ‘Smile, you are on camera,'” she said. “They look very professional.”

“We need to really treasure where we live and do our best to help, if we have the help and the strength to make our surroundings beautiful,” said Cook-Bibb, who is also president of the Brownville community, which consists of three neighborhoods. “And dumping is certainly not beautiful.”

Cook-Bibb’s ideas get results and get noticed. In 2022, she received a community service award for being a neighborhood officer and for organizing neighborhood cleanups during Covid. In 2024, she received a “Shero Award’’ for organizing neighborhood meeting conference calls during Covid. Both were given by the Community First organization.

When Cook-Bibb is not fighting to improve her neighborhood, she’s fighting pounds at the gym. She goes three times a week, and she’s found it helps her stay on course to do all the things she needs to do.

“‘My friends tell me, ‘Aww, girl. You’ve just got energy.’ I say, no you just have to keep to going. If you stop, your energy stops,” she said. “This was my year. I turned 75 on Jan. 25, and I’m so blessed that God has allowed me to be here.”

March 29 – Tomeka Walker

Tomeka Walker was 22 weeks pregnant when she gave birth to her son, Khairi, in 2014. He lived for 2.5 hours before he died at the hospital.

The premature birth was unexpected, and Khairi’s death was heartbreaking, especially since Walker said she did not have any problems during pregnancy. Khairi passed on a Monday and one day later, Walker had to call funeral homes and cemeteries to get pricing for his burial.

Walker was not prepared for what she learned. Some places wanted to charge $5,000 and up to cover a casket, the opening and closing for the grave, etc. Another place wanted $2,500. The grief. The costs. The shock. It was enough to push one over the edge. She was at a loss.

But Walker persevered and found a plan that fit her budget. As she worked on the paperwork, she wondered how many other women experienced what she had and how many of them faced financial hardships in burying a baby.

To help others, Walker started the Khairi and Little Angels’ Memorial in 2014.

For low-income women who’ve lost babies from 20 weeks’ gestation to 12 months of age, and they are unable to pay for a burial, Walker’s organization can assist with expenses at two funeral homes and one cemetery they have partnered with in this effort. Coverage costs vary. They don’t do cover funeral services. And depending on costs, they usually don’t pay for headstones.

Walker said they have paid for 20 burials since 2017, and they use fundraising and donations to help pay for the burials.

When Walker was looking for a plot for Khairi, cemeteries had plots for adults. She was told her the same price for an adult grave would be the same price for a baby. However, at the cemetery the organization partners with, there is a “Babyland,” where the plots are smaller and not as expensive. Walker helped establish it. Mothers submit applications to the organization to be considered for coverage.

“I feel like, to a lot of families, I’m a blessing. I’ve had a lot of them come back to me and tell me they don’t know what they would have done if they had not found me,” Walker said. “I know God called me to do this, and I know, each time that I do it, I feel like my heart is smiling because I know Khairi is smiling.”

The organization also helps make women more aware of their bodies when they are pregnant; aware of their health and life insurance coverage when it comes to time in the hospital and the untimely passing of a child; encourage them to be strong advocates for their health when dealing with doctors; and to be aware of the organization’s maternal mental health resources. Starting in April 2024, they will offer childbirth education classes. In September 2024, they will host a mental health expo at the A.G. Boys and Girls Club. They include other events on their website, www.klamemorial.org.

“I want to be able to help families and women not endure the heartache that I did,” said Walker, who has written two books that include stories from women who’ve lost their babies during or after childbirth. “I will have flashbacks, periodically, of trying to navigate through the burials and calling around to get prices. And I don’t want families to experience that.”

“If anyone wants to join us, they can sign up as a volunteer, they can call me, or they sign up online.”

To contact Walker, email info@klamemorial.org.

March 29 – Irina Pritchett

For the last two years, Irina Pritchett has volunteered as a mentor with the non-profit group Momentum to help women at different stages in their careers.

Pritchett has helped mentees stand out in their resumes, improve interview skills and sharpen their ability to maneuver the workplace. For one mentee interviewing for a job, Pritchett stressed to her the importance of having confidence and being an advocate for oneself.

“She did get the job, and since then, her career is huge. It’s exploding,” Pritchett said.

Pritchett, 38, had mentors in college, grad school and when she switched from working at a college in a Ph.D. program to the banking industry, which is why she said it is important to volunteer through Momentum. The non-profit Birmingham organization offers different programs to elevate women, addressing everything from executive leadership to women just getting started in a career.

“With Momentum, I really love to give a platform to a program that is this awesome,” said Pritchett, who has a doctorate in economics and works in downtown Birmingham at Regions bank. “They are so deliberate on how they connect people.”

She is also a board member of Central Six AlabamaWorks, a workforce development council that forms industry and educational partnerships to create sustainable career paths for those already working and for once-employed individuals get back to work. It serves Jefferson, Blount, Chilton, Shelby, St. Clair and Walker counties.

In mid-October 2024, the council will bring the Worlds of Work exhibit to the Birmingham CrossPlex to give area eighth graders hands-on experience of what jobs are like in different professions. She plans to volunteer at the event.

“If you are doing something that is important to you, if you are following your passion, I think there is some element of ease to it because it gives back to you as much as you give in to it,” she said.

Pritchett, who was 4 years old when her family immigrated from Belarus to America as political refugees, was able to help again when a bank co-worker sponsored a family of five, who had fled the war in the Ukraine in late 2022. The community and bank co-workers came together to help the family settle into the area. Pritchett and a different bank co-worker served as interpreters and pitched in with her other co-workers to help the family, who opened a local bridal shop in 2023.

For Pritchett, empowerment isn’t just a goal; it’s also the anchor of community strength.

“This city is filled with amazing humans, including amazing women, and anything that helps empower us to be ourselves in this community with authenticity … it contributes to the strength of the city,” Pritchett said.

For more information on Momentum, visit momentumleaders.org. For more information on Central Six AlabamaWorks, visit centralsix.org.

March 30 – Dora Sims

With her keen sense of leadership and boundless energy, Dora Sims has helped implement initiatives aimed at enhancing the quality of life for residents in the Five Points community.

Every month for a year in 2022, the community hosted neighborhood cleanups to reduce crime. They also created a newsletter to keep residents and schools in the district informed about happenings in their area. Community members liked the impact of their efforts and decided

to share the results with a larger audience.

So, in 2023, Sims joined others to present their concept and case study during the Neighborhoods USA (NUSA) conference in El Paso, Texas. The Five Points community, which includes Belview Heights, Bush Hills, Central Park, Ensley Highlands, Fairview and Green Acres neighborhoods, won second place in the “Multi-Neighborhood Category” at NUSA. Sims was excited about the win and returned to Birmingham with even bigger goals: improving community development, education, economic development and the environment.

“I do this because it’s important to be engaged in your neighborhood and where you live,” said Sims, who is a past president of the Five Points community and is the current vice president of the Bush Hills neighborhood. “When we give back and encourage others to give back, we create a safe place to live and raise our families.”

Sims is also a member of the Bush Hills Connection Education Committee. Each year, she joins committee members at Birmingham’s Bush Hills STEAM Academy to welcome back students on the first day of school. Her community is where her heart is, which is why she visits the school, listens attentively to the concerns of her neighbors, amplifies residents’ voices and works to find solutions that benefit everyone.

Recognizing the importance of economic vitality in the area, Sims has taken on the challenge of helping to revamp the vision and mission of the Five Points West CrossPlex Business Alliance. With her strategic vision and approach, she wants to network with businesses in the Five Points West corridor and connect them with resources and more people in the community. She also wants to establish a board, which will re-examine the alliance’s by-laws.

“As a resident and neighbor, I am concerned about where I live. I want to be able to help create this place where we can enjoy the quality of life without having to leave and find that elsewhere,” Sims said. “I feel like I’m on a good path right now. Working with the businesses will help strengthen our neighborhood community and pull everything together.”

March 30 – Dr. Nancy Tofil

Dr. Nancy Tofil wears many hats at Children’s of Alabama.

She is a professor of pediatrics, the director of the Division of Pediatric Critical Care and the senior associate program director for the hospital’s Pediatric Residency Program. These areas see patients anywhere from 3 or 4 days old up to 26 years old with brain tumors, Covid, pneumonia, burns, gunshot wounds, kidney and liver transplants and scoliosis surgery.

Another responsibility she holds is serving as the founder and medical director of the hospital’s Simulation Center and Pediatric Intensive Care Unit, where medical students, nurses, fellows, faculty and more gain hands-on experience to increase their knowledge, hone their skills and practice teamwork in real-life patient scenarios.

What’s a simulator? Think Annie the CPR mannequin from your high school days. It was static and lifeless as you practiced your CPR moves back in the day. The old simulator medical students had was sort of like that. It lacked the ability to breathe or give a pulse like a real person would. If students needed to experience what it was like for the old simulator to breathe, for example, Dr. Tofil would have to tell them the simulator was breathing.

In 2006, Dr. Tofil heard there was a new and improved simulator available. And in 2007, the hospital secured a high-fidelity, high-realism simulator that functions just a like a human.

With the new simulator, Dr. Tofil opened the Simulation Center in 2008. Today, the center has 12 computer-controlled simulators of all sizes, from a preemie to a teenager. They breathe. They have a pulse. They can talk. Some have eyes that open and close. The simulators also have monitors that allow students to administer medicine, and the simulator will react to the medicine. Students can also practice procedures.

“I work in ICU eight weeks a year, and then the rest of the year is spent working in the Simulation Center, teaching people, solving problems and watching residents grow,” said Dr. Tofil, 51. “It’s exciting and different.”

Under Dr. Tofil’s guidance, the Simulation Center has become one of the most active pediatric simulation centers in the country. With each training session, students gain invaluable experience that translates directly to better patient care for children throughout the state. Since opening, the center has seen 94,000 learners.

In October 2023, Dr. Tofil received the Wallace Alexander Clyde Distinguished Service Award for Excellence in Pediatrics from the Alabama chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics for her work with the center.

Through Dr. Tofil’s dedication and vision, she continues to shape the future of healthcare, one simulator at a time.

March 31 – Angela Scott Abdur-Rasheed

Angela Scott Abdur-Rasheed is using the power of her pen to get Birmingham businesses and non-profit organizations noticed beyond the borders of the Magic City.

She does it as director of communications and community engagement for Prosper, a non-profit organization that offers small businesses and nonprofit groups access to capital, resources and technical assistance to help build their business and Birmingham in lasting and inclusive ways. The group also does workforce development for high school students and training for small businesses.

Abdur-Rasheed’s profiles delve into the heart of what makes each company or organization unique, sharing their journey, their struggles and how they are making a difference in Birmingham.

“I write features on a lot of the people that participate in the programs we fund, or they have received funding from us so they can be shown and known to an audience broader than their customer base,” said the Birmingham native, who is 52, married and has two stepchildren.

Through her storytelling, Birmingham’s hidden gems come to life and highlight the city’s entrepreneurial spirit. There are victories, where dreams are realized, and obstacles are overcome. There are defeats, where setbacks and challenges test even the most determined. And then, there are rebounds, moments of resilience a business owner musters up to fight another day, refusing to be deterred.

One of Abdur-Rasheed’s business profiles caught the attention of the Scripps News network. It was Naughty But Nice Kettle Corn Co., a Woodlawn-based, female-run business that has participated in different cohorts offered by Prosper. Scripps News sent an Atlanta camera crew to Birmingham to interview Naughty But Nice founder and CEO Tanesha Sims-Summers in November 2023. Another crew from Florida did a Zoom interview with her.

Naughty But Nice “has received an influx of national business; people who ordinarily would not have known about them,” Abdur-Rasheed said, adding that the story did not run in Birmingham because the city does not have a Scripps News Network station here. “That can be transformative for that business.”

Abdur-Rasheed, who is the author of seven books, has also used her storytelling talents for when Prosper and organizations from Birmingham visit cities for big conferences and events. Prosper and its partners have started to see additional results from such exposure.

“If we don’t know our story, tell it and have a vehicle to reach the right ears, we could be missing out on just that next thing to elevate us as a city, community or individual,” she said.

This year will mark the third anniversary for Prosper, and to celebrate, organizers will host a community-centered event on Thursday, June 13. It will start at 4 p.m. with an annual report of reflections of 2023 and projections for 2024. Then, it will close with a Prosper birthday celebration from 5:30 to 7 p.m.

People must pre-register to attend at https://prosperannualmeeting.swell.gives/

“This will not be like your traditional annual meeting where it’s just the board of directors, staff or stakeholders,” said Abdur-Rasheed, who added that the event is for everyone, including CEOs, entrepreneurs, neighborhood leaders and residents.

Another upcoming Propser event will be the Let’s Connect Luncheon for Faith, Neighborhood and Civic Leaders on Thursday, April 25. To attend, email Abdur-Rasheed at arasheed@prosperbham.com. For more info on Prosper, visit www.prosperbham.com.

Events like these emphasize how storytelling can unite communities, celebrate achievements and amplify voices that may otherwise go unheard. As Birmingham continues to evolve, Abdur-Rasheed remains dedicated to showcasing stories that reflect the richness and diversity of the city and its residents.

March 31 – Dr. Erica Stringer-Reasor

When Dr. Erica Stringer-Reasor enrolled in medical school, she had visions of becoming an eye surgeon.

Growing up and seeing her grandmother diagnosed with glaucoma left Dr. Stringer-Reasor wanting to find a way to impact sight for people. But by the time Dr. Stringer-Reasor started medical school at the University of South Alabama in Mobile, a classmate and student mentor would eventually change her whole plan.

The classmate, Regan Robinson Young, was diagnosed with Stage 4 colon cancer in her 20s, which was a total surprise as colon cancer is often diagnosed in people over the age of 60. Young, who was a year ahead of Dr. Stringer-Reasor in medical school, underwent chemotherapy and surgery while continuing with school. However, Young died four months before graduation.

Young’s passing affected Dr. Stringer-Reasor and other classmates. “After she died, I knew right then that I wanted to do something in women’s health – in oncology,” said Dr. Stringer-Reasor, who graduated in 2008. She would later turn her focus toward ovarian cancer and later breast ca
